squidpony.squidmath

Class WhirlingNoise

  • java.lang.Object
    • squidpony.squidmath.PerlinNoise
      • squidpony.squidmath.WhirlingNoise
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Noise.Noise2D, Noise.Noise3D, Noise.Noise4D

    @Beta
public class WhirlingNoise
extends PerlinNoise
implements Noise.Noise2D, Noise.Noise3D, Noise.Noise4D, Serializable
    Another experimental noise class. Extends PerlinNoise and should have similar quality, but can be faster and has less periodic results. This is still considered experimental because the exact output may change in future versions, along with the scale (potentially) and the parameters it takes. In general, noise(double, double) and noise(double, double, double) should have similar appearance to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double), PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double), and PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double, double), but are not forced to a zoomed-in scale like PerlinNoise makes its results, have a lower chance of forming shapes with multiple octaves that appear "non-natural" (such as long straight lines, axis-aligned shapes, and hard angles), and the 3D and 4D noise variants tend to be faster due to a more efficient method for hashing points. WhirlingNoise is preferred to other related Noise.Noise3D or Noise.Noise4D implementations for most world map generation (usually using WorldMapGenerator) because it is less likely to produce artificial-seeming shapes, which are out-of-place in a world map.
    Created by Tommy Ettinger on 12/14/2016. The technique for point hashing here is based closely on this paper, with credit to Andrew Kensler, Aaron Knoll and Peter Shirley.
    See Also:

      • grad3f

        protected static final float[][] grad3f
        The 32 3D vertices of a rhombic triacontahedron. These were modified from values taken from Vladimir Bulatov's stellation applet, which has available source but is unlicensed, and is available here, but the vertices are mathematical constants so copyright isn't an issue.

      • gradCoord3D

        protected static double gradCoord3D(long seed,
                                    int x,
                                    int y,
                                    int z,
                                    double xd,
                                    double yd,
                                    double zd)
        Computes the hashing for an integer point and its dot product with a double point as one step. This code is largely drawn from Jordan Peck's MIT-licensed code, https://github.com/Auburns/FastNoise_Java , present in SquidLib as FastNoise.
        Parameters:
        seed -
        x -
        y -
        z -
        xd -
        yd -
        zd -
        Returns:
        a double between -1.25 and 1.25, I think

      • getNoise

        public double getNoise(double x,
                       double y)
        2D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.
        Specified by:
        getNoise in interface Noise.Noise2D
        Parameters:
        x - X input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        y - Y input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • getNoiseWithSeed

        public double getNoiseWithSeed(double x,
                               double y,
                               long seed)
        Identical to getNoise(double, double); ignores seed.
        Specified by:

        Parameters:

        seed - ignored entirely.
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

        3D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.

Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.

      • noise

        public static double noise(double xin,
                           double yin)
        2D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.
        Parameters:
        xin - X input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        yin - Y input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

        public static double noise(double x,
                           double y,
                           double z,
                           double w)
        4D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise, plus it has less chance of repetition in chunks because it uses a pseudo-random function (curiously, ThrustAltRNG.determine(long), which has very good distribution and is fast) instead of a number chosen by hash from a single 256-element array.

        y - Y input
        z - Z input
        w - W input (fourth-dimensional)
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • noise

        public static double noise(double x,
                           double y,
                           double z,
                           double w,
                           long seed)
        4D simplex noise. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double, double) and this method. Roughly 20-25% faster than the equivalent method in PerlinNoise.
        Parameters:
        x - X input
        y - Y input
        z - Z input
        w - W input (fourth-dimensional)
        seed - any int; will be used to completely alter the noise
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • noiseAlt

        public static float noiseAlt(double x,
                             double y)
        2D simplex noise returning a float; extremely similar to noise(double, double), but this may be slightly faster or slightly slower. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double) and this method. This also cannot take a seed, while noise(double, double, long) can.
        Parameters:
        x - x input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        y - y input; works well if between 0.0 and 1.0, but anything is accepted
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive

      • noiseAlt

        public static float noiseAlt(double x,
                             double y,
                             double z)
        3D simplex noise returning a float; extremely similar to noise(double, double, double), but this may be slightly faster or slightly slower. Unlike PerlinNoise, uses its parameters verbatim, so the scale of the result will be different when passing the same arguments to PerlinNoise.noise(double, double, double) and this method. This also cannot take a seed, while noise(double, double, double, long) can.
        Parameters:
        x - X input
        y - Y input
        z - Z input
        Returns:
        noise from -1.0 to 1.0, inclusive
